description.text: I modified the latch for mounting inside an Ikea Stave mirror, which comes with hinges, but no way to latch it closed.

You'll need the original catch, which I did not modify, but note that it has to be mounted with a slight offset to avoid banging into the mounts. (If it bothered me, I'd probably just trim down the height of the catch by 3mm.) The curious arrangement of holes is so that it fits an Ikea Stave mirror: http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/80178424/#/80223520

description.text:
Update 0ct 12 2016 noticed the adjustment screw was too close for comfort and pushed it back another 2.7mm

Not Sure why but seems my P802M is different than the other users on here. In this case I printed P802m motor mount (zonestar) by dsol (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1354016) only to notice the z endstop adjuster is in a different space on my model. anyway rather that reprint the entire thing I made this repair kit it just snaps on or can be glued. If you have the same model as me and have not already printed dsol's Original I would recommend (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821774) this model is only to save filament if you have already printed the original like I had. Also if anyone knows Why my P802M is different that everyone elses (what model is it really?) please do comment I am looking to upgrade my cooling fan as well however the others posted here will not fit the model I have

description.text:
The Blood Rage board-game is a wonderful game about viking fighting, dying with honor during the Ragnarok (end-of-the-world).

More info : https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/170216/blood-rage

Blood Rage was financed with a Kickstarter campaign and their was some "Kickstarter exclusive" mini... along them was Fenrir, the monster-wolf.

This mini is a proxy for all of us that came late to Blood Rage but want to try to play with Fenrir and the other "Kickstarter exclusive".

I am full aware that this mini is at level with the original art (https://boardgamegeek.com/image/2713921/blood-rage) but then.... you had to be there on time :p

You can find other proxies for Blood Rage here : http://www.thingiverse.com/agademer/collections/blood-rage

print_settings.Notes:: For the clip, print however you want.  I used 0.1984mm @ 15% infill.

description.text: My daughters wanted some unicorn horns, so I modeled these up and printed them. They look really good in a translucent material, then you can stick in a lightstick and they glow in the dark!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1984mm

Infill:

Varies

Notes:

I printed the Horn as a spiral vase with a wall thickness of 0.8mm and no bottom (in slicer). Put a fan on it, it'll help with quality towards the end.

For the clip, print however you want. I used 0.1984mm @ 15% infill.

I used some off-the shelf elastic from Ben Franklin, but the slots and clips are designed to accommodate a 1mm x 9.5mm band, so whatever works. Just use em like regular straps, and you can change the fit, or just sew em, and throw those little bits away.

It helps to squeeze the base of the horn a little bit to pop the clip in, but it holds well.
Rhinoceros 3D

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus Side Filament Guide

description.text:
Intended to be used along with a PTFE tube, filament guide can be rotated to suit your arrangement. Rotating portion is not designed to spin freely, it holds in place once the part is attached. You could probably sand it or downscale it slightly if you'd like it to fit loose.

I used 4 m3 x 16mm screws to secure it to the printer, be careful when choosing hardware to ensure the screws do not stick far enough back they can interfere with Z/X movement.

Part is designed in Inches, based off the i3 Plus, I am not certain if it will fit others. Screw spacing is a 1 3/16" square.

...Model is in Inches! Depending on your slicer you may have to manually scale to CM, or say Yes when it asks if you want to auto-scale!...

description.text:
My son is currently addicted to the Lion Guard (Disney Junior), and since we have a 3D printer (MakerBot Mini) in our house (Christmas present to me from my husband... yes, he is amazing!), my son always wants to print something. He's got the toy characters from Disney with the little Lion Guard figures, and I wanted to encourage him to have a "home" for everything at the end of the night. So, this is Pride Rock, and wherever we put Pride Rock, that is where all the toys will go at night.

At least that's the theory.

It's all original. If I added anything, I would add texture to the mountains and such, but it's good for Kion to stand upon and roar.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online to your heart's content! https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bwf1GMFbsKM

description.text:
Perch for your glasses to sit on top of your monitor.

Prescription eyeglasses are now available online for ~$10. It makes sense to keep a pair at every computer. This is a place for you to keep your computer glasses when not using them, or your ordinary glasses when you are.

Every monitor is different in thickness, the angles the top and back make compared to the screen, and so on. Use the customizer to adjust to fit your monitor. You can choose to make a test profile that's just wide enough to check whether it fits your monitor, or you can get the STL for the full width version and stop it after a few layers.

This is not a great design. I could have made the pieces much thinner and rigidized it with gussets. Making it adjustable after printing, instead of customizable before, would be a lot more convenient. The Nose could use a lot more whimsy. Feel free to improve it.

If you customize it for a different monitor, leave the monitor model and the values you changed in a comment and describe how well it fits. The baseline values are for a 2013 iMac 27".

author: harddrv1

title: The Chimeric Printrbot Simple Metal: A complete dual extruder upgrade using E3D's Chimera compact dual v6 system
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Last updated 12/14/2017
Note #1: As of the end of December 2016, the dual extruder system is now fully operational and all components including fan shrouds are published. This project is listed as "in progress" as I have continued to add helpful commentary and try to improve clarity over time.

Note #2: When I started looking at dual extruder systems for the Printrbot Simple Metal, I wished I could just buy a kit, as the process appeared much more difficult than it turned to be. I greatly appreciated those people who extensively documented their work because it made my project much easier. So I am trying to do my part to make things easier for those who come after me. I have tried to provide the detail needed so that anyone who is inclined to build one too can (hopefully) replicate my project without too much anguish. If you have any questions about the project, message or post questions here and I will do what I can to answer.

This is the latest upgrade to my early model Printrbot Simple Metal: an E3D Chimera dual extruder system. Having already installed a heated bed, and upgraded the X and Z axes from 6" to 10", I had been using an increasing number of 'exotic filaments pushing the limits of the ceramic ubis hot end. I needed to expand my available temperature range with an all metal hot end. I also wanted to print with dissolving supports pretty much from the moment I broke my first print trying to remove support material.

E3D's v6 based Chimera system looked prefect. It was highly compact, meaning that I would loose very little build space to the second extruder. The small aluminum component would be unlikely to weigh the Y arm down. The design also had a fixed distance between perfectly parallel extruders, making the usual fiddly adjustments that come with dual extruder printing much easier. The basis of the system was the respected all metal E3D v6. Exactly what I would get if I was just upgrading to a single all metal hot end. And finally, being a molecular biologist whose last work was building conditional transgenics, the name appealed to me and allowed some mol bio humor wordplay.

I had been gathering components as genuine E3D parts came down in price with the decline of the pound after the Brexit vote. But the real push was when the heater died on my ceramic ubis. I wasn't about too buy another hot end when I had the Chimera in hand. Only a few days before the ubis died, I found out about techyfiddler's Bowden extruder mount for the Simple metal (see pictures above and http://www.thingiverse.com/make:260137), which solved the problem of where to place the second extruder while allowing me to use the existing Alu extruder for the first hot end. And with that, I started Chimerizing my Printrbot, a process which turned out to be considerably less complicated and difficult than I had feared it would be. Although it required quite a bit of searching, the major troubles I faced turned out to be previously encountered and solved. I hope these instructions will make it almost as easy to set up a Chimera dual extruder on the Printrbot simple metal, as attach one of Printrbot's axis or heated bed upgrade kits. Enough so that if you can do the later, you can do the former.

Special Thanks go to:
techyfiddler for his attachment for a Bowen mount extruder for the Simple Metal. This was the solution to the problem that had made me reluctant to start the modification. Without it, I probably would not have started the conversion yet,let alone be finished.
pin13 for his Sidewinder fan shroud and for graciously providing .step files and a mirror image version.
SchusterConcepts for the Y axis cable guide I use to keep the Bowden extruder servo wires out of the way.
joeydaphish for his Y extension, likely my next project and how I will not only recover the 18mm of Y space I'm loosing but will grab more
cporto for the idea on modifying the fan shroud tip for better cooling of the print and less of the hot end..
and reprap.me for still selling extrudrboards
NEWS FLASH (9/8/17): Printrbot store now selling extrudrboards as part of their multi-color/material extruder community project.

Overview, Methods and Tools

Despite fearing that the process would be daunting, I was pleasantly surprised that mounting the hardware was straightforward. With the exception of the printed Bowden mount, I have been able to attach the Chimera using adaptors made from simple aluminum plates, making complicated milling of metal parts or design of complex shapes to print unnecessary. I was able to easily and quickly fabricate with the metal cutting bandsaw, drill-press, and other power and hand-tools I already owned. While a drill press and 3mm tap for cutting threads would be very helpful, all the metalwork could be done with only a hacksaw, some files, and a power drill with a couple bits and one hole saw. Alternatively, someone with better software and/or more capacity for 3D design than I, could design printable plastic versions of my aluminum plates. At some point in the future I may do this although the metalwork is pretty trivial for anyone who has done the most basic of woodwork. If you can cut and drill wood, you can do the same in aluminum.

One comment about non-E3D parts: If you search online, you'll see that there are lots of inexpensive knock-offs of E3D designed and produced (in the UK) products including the Chimera. If you search forum posts, you will also see that they are hit or miss,mostly miss, for quality with lots of headaches trying to get them to work well, if they work at all. I went with authentic E3D products from an authorized distributor and they have worked flawlessly from the first print. There are times you get what you pay for. This I believe is one of them. Buy a real Chimera direct from E3D or an authorized distributor in the U.S. In other cases, you can save quite a bit by buying direct from China instead of having E3D buy from China and sell it to you at a markup (for example cables and the extruder stepper motor). So caveat emptor.

Mounting Hardware

The mounting hardware is shown in the images marked A through D. The chimera mounts to a 1/4" thick aluminum plate (65mmx40mm) via the screw holes on the top of the heat sink. The holes for the heat sink attachment are positioned using the provided file CHIMERA-ASSEMBLED.eps (copyright E3D, provided here under what I believe are fair use provisions) printed at 50% size (or whatever % produces a print where the lengths indicated in the drawing are the same length on the print). Taped securely in place, this print is then used as a template to drill all 3 holes with a 3mm drill bit. Note that the side with 2 screws faces towards the side with the fan. This template can also be used to drill the holes for the extruder openings, 5/16 to 3/8"for the Bowden extruder, 5/8" for the Alu direct drive. Be sure to leave at least 1mm between the edge of these holes and the holes that are used to attach the Chimera heat sink. This will place the filament entry for the direct drive slightly offset from the center of the hole in the aluminum plates. In image C and D, the red filaments marking the screws attaching the Chimera heat sink, the yellow filaments the actual path of filaments from extruders to hot ends. The screw heads are recessed into the plate so that they are below the plane of the Y-arm. This is done by drilling with a bit slightly larger bit than the heads of the screws used, just deep enough so that the heads do not protrude.

As shown in the image marked B, this plate is attached to the simple metal via a 3 screws that use 2 of the original 3 holes used for the screws holding the Alu extruder to the Y-arm (the third original hole is blocked by the Chimera's fan). The 3rd attachment screw uses the one hole on the extruder not employed in the original Printrbot design and required drilling a 3mm hole in the Y-arm at the appropriate location (a template can be made by tracing the underside of the Alu extruder). These screws also secure a longer, 3/16" thick metal plate (80mmx40mm) is sandwiched between the Y arm and the Alu extruder as shown in the photo marked B. This plate has holes drilled in it identical to those used to pass the filaments and screws to hold the Alu extruder. This plate should extend partially under the Alu extruder servo . Note that In B, the red filaments show the locations of the holes used for 3mm screws to connect the assembly to the Y arm and extruder in the order (bottom to top): 1/4"plate,Y-arm, 3/16" plate, extruder. The extruder holes are threaded and no nut is required.

The Chimera is set up as described in the online E3D instructions. The first end may be 'direct drive' but I ended up constructing it like a minimal length Bowden system, with the plastic Bowden attachments placed in both heat sink openings. A groovemount adaptor is held firm in the clutches of the extruder with a very short length of PTFE tubing to the second hot end. This permitted me to offset the filament entry port from the Alu adaptor very slightly so as to have adequate margins around the screw holes. Initially the Bowden extruder was mounted vertically on the top of the smooth Z risers. But following a comment by techyfiddler about his being horizontally mounted, I realized with my setup,this was a better way to go providing better filament paths (see pictures). You are welcome to set it up however suits your needs best.

Note that in the photo, the 3/16" plate ends with a downward bend as I had originally planned to attach a print cooling fan for the second hot end here. The 80mmx40mm size does not include this addition. This did not turn out to be the best location and so this spot is used only for attaching cables for organization and is not necessary nor is the length needed to have it included in these instructions. Second, in several photos there are more holes cut than needed because I either screwed up or changed my mind about what worked best. As these were not visible I saw no need to fabricate new parts. If you make a mistake, you can do the same! Realize that as none of the holes drilled so far ends up being threaded, so there is considerable wiggle room for enlarging a hole so that the screws fit through perpendicular to the plane of the attachment plates. The important part is that the screws fit square to the heatsink and Alu extruder. I found that clamping the plates together in place made placing and tightening screws much easier.

The fan for the first hot end was originally to be moved slightly proximal using an aluminum bar attached to the original fan attachment point. Looking for fan shroud models I found a promising model called the Sidewinder that the author, Pin13, graciously modified to a mirror image of the shroud he used for his chimera (on a different printer, see here. I had originally planned to place the second fan at the end of the Alu extruder spacer plate. It became apparent that mounting to the side of the spacer bar (via yet another plate, 1/8" thick.54mmx42mm with the bend at 42mm and a semicircular cut-out) made more sense. The plate was eventually attached by 3 screws, as shown in picture 1, such that the side of the plate closest to the Z probe is flush up against the Y arm. Three 3mm holes are drilled in the 1/8" plate plate in a triangular pattern. The exact locations are not critical. The 1/8" plate is placed where it will sit on the 3/16" plate and 3/32" or 2.5mm drilled through the 3mm holes into the 3/16" plates. The 3/32" or 2.5mm holes are then tapped with a 3mm tap to thread them. Holes in the 3/16" plate for attachment of the 1/8" plate are threaded so no nuts are needed.

If you don't know how to tap threads see this instructable or this skill builder published in the March 2017 issue of MAKE. It is much easier than it sounds. Because you will be cutting aluminum with steel, you can get away without cutting fluid for lubrication but the task is much easier with it. I'm a fan of "TAP Magic EP-xtra". If you move on to cutting threads in harder metals like steel you must use cutting fluid unless you want to break taps off, ruining the holes you drilled. Start a good habit with your first taps, and use the stuff when drilling metal to prolong bit life.

The sidewinder design (use the mirror version) work fairly well as is, though the one on the Bowden extruder will need to be trimmed down,and the one on the Alu side should be longer. The photos above all show the printer with the uncustomized fan shrouds. I have modified them and adapted the nozzles to aim more towards the print. I got this idea from cporto's shroud. Modified Sidewinder shrouds designed for this specific application are found here. Modified spacing adaptors to ft these shrouds are found here. For the most effective cooling, I recommend replacing the 40mm square fans with 50mmx15mm blower fans and using 40mm adaptors from WaveSupportApparatus. My makes of these attached to the Chimeric printrbot simple metal are here.

Bowden Extruder

To make things easy I used the E3D Titan extruder for my Bowden setup. I printed techyfiddler's mount while my ceramic Ubis still worked. If you didn't, you can print this after you get the first E3D hot end working. You may need to tweak the sizes a bit and/or use a 12mm drill to ream out the holes to get it to fit snugly. Both PLA and ABS work fine. ABS shrinks more but is less brittle. The Titan was bought from Filastruder, an authorized US distributor. I bought the recommended Wantai Model No.42BYGHW609 from Banggood though there are many sources direct from China on ebay, in addition to E3D from the UK. The Titan is assembled as per the online instruction. Note that the Titan does not extrude at the same rate as the Alu extruder. See the final adjustments below for how to compensate for the discrepancy.

Electronic Hardware and Software

To get started printing again, the first E3Dv6 hot end and thermistor was connected to the printrboard by hijacking the wires used by the original thermistor and ceramic Ubis hot end. They weren't using them anymore! Be aware that the heater element for the first hot end can hit the chassis of the printrbit on zeroing the z axis if it is sticking too far out. The 30mm fan for cooling the Chimera was hardwired directly into a 12V power line from my ATX power supply. There is no harm in having it running whenever the machine is powered up, but there can be a lot of harm in not running it while the hot end is heated.

The firmware must be altered to account for two temp sensors (change TEMP_SENSOR0 and 1 to type 5, leave TEMP_SENSOR2 as type 1), increase MAXTEMP on these extruders to 290 or 300, as well as entering the correct size of the build plate. I have included modified firmware for rev.F printrboards as complied files in several versions, as well as the Arduino IDE files to modify it yourself. Guides to doing this can be found at both:

http://matterhackers.dozuki.com/Guide/How+to+Install+an+E3D+v6+HotEnd+on+a+Printrbot+Simple+Metal/9

http://thisoldspoon.blogspot.com.au/2015/03/e3d-v6-hotend-on-printrbot-simple-metal.html

In addition, you can message me and I'll try to help you out.

Once this is done, you will need to autotune the hot end so that it heats to the required level without much overshoot. This is described in both guides above.Then you'll need to set the Z offset (which you should be familiar with by now). At this point, I was abe to start printing with the first extruder.

To get the second going, you will need to install an extrudrboard. The first step is to solder headers (CAREFULLY!) onto your Printrboard at the two rows of 7 holes marked Exp1. These are connected to the pins marked Exp 1 on the Extrudrboard in the same order relative to the print "EXP1" via flat cables with dupont connectors (I used Banggood item here which worked fine and also provided the connector for the Bowden servo. To make the connections the provided diagram of the extrudrboard helps.

The power cord uses the same 6 pin connector as the Rev F printrboard (i.e. (6 pin, 3x2, "PCIe" type). If you can't find any other source, you can always buy the 4pin to 6 pin power extension from Printrbot, cut off the 4 pin side and wire the 6 pin connector to your ATX +12V line and ground lines. Otherwise, just wire the ATX +12V power and ground lines to the connector. I'm assuming you don't need me to tell you that the red goes to the +12V and black to ground, but you might need me to tell you that the side of the connector with the clip is the ground side.

The servo is attached at the site marked Mot-A. Using the same servo I used, starting in the square and moving left on the above diagram, servo wire colors are: Blue, Red, Black, Green.

Figure out where you want to place the extrudrboard under the chassis. My photos show what I think is the easiest spot with the most space for wires. Regardless of where you located it, make sure you have clearance for the wiring.. Drill 3mm holes in the correct spots (to use screws, nylon spacers, and nuts) or 3/32" or 2.5mm holes and tap (to use screws and nylon spacers). In case it wasn't obvious,do not have the metal contacts on the underside of the extrudrboard touch the metal on the chassis. Use spacers.

To get the second hot end temp to read correctly (rather than reading about 175C when at room temp and turning off the extruder due to MINTEMP errors), THERM-B on the extruderboard must have either a Ubis thermistor attached (as I show in my photos), or a 100K ohm resistor across the two terminals. But that's not all! To avoid giant oscillations (>20C) in hot end temp you must take at least one if not two more steps. You need a large wire, 12G or so, connecting one mounting post of the extrudrboard to the printrboard. You may find this is enough. I did not nor did some others using non-Printrbot extrudrboards. To eliminate the oscillations, connect only one side of the 2nd hot end E3D thermistor to directly to one of the THERM-A terminals. Wire the other terminal to a mounting post on the extrudrboard. This is shown in my photos.

To help you identify locations on the extrudr- and printrboards, I have included schematics and photos that I found helpful. I did not make any of these. Sources are as indicated.

Extrudrboard layout from Reprap Electronics (https://github.com/Printrbot/printrboard) Photo of Printrboard RevF5 (from 3DPrint.com) Printrboard RevF layout (from Printrbot Talk Forum, credit to RetireeJay) Photo of Extrudrboard (from RepRapSquad)

Final Adjustments

To keep cables out of the way, I used SchusterConcepts Y axis cable guide. This may require a bit of dremel work to provide space for the extrudrboard mountung screws. I used this one because it made it easy to have the Titan extruder servo cables join the rest of the Y axis cables.

At this point you will need to set the correct offset. The extruders tips are precisely 18mm from each other. If you are perfectly aligned, X offset zero,Y offset 18 will do it and test prints using various calibration prints will be perfect. If you are like me they are a little off, yielding a fraction of a mm for X offset and a Y offset a fraction of a mm away from 18mm.

I have yet to find a way to set the second extruder fan separate from the first using software. The best I have come up with is to manually control the speed using a 500ohm potentiometer. If anyone figures out a better way, I'd love to find out.

Lastly, if you use the Titan extruder, be aware that running at standard rotation speed the Titan extrudes at about 1/5th the rate of the Alu extruder. By weight, the ratio is 5.17 Titan to 1 Alu. I have not been able to find in the firmware how to have it run at 5.17x the Alu speed all the time. But if you set extrusion rate at 5.17x for the Titan hot end and 1x for the Alu hot end, it all comes out fine.

title: Heavy Duty Pan and Tilt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE - 7 February, 2017 - A poster on RCG, Relaxincherry, has successfully worked to get these parts available in Europe. Here is the link to the European source:

StepLab - https://www.steplab.net/prodotto/giunti-per-servo-da-38/

UPDATE - 20 January, 2017 - Because getting the aluminum coupler has been a problem for anyone outside the US I have created a print that will replace it using a Futaba servo wheel. The new part is Futaba_Servo_Coupler_v2.stl and requires an additional four M2 x 8mm screws and nuts for assembly.

For those not in the US who still want to use the aluminum 25 tooth servo shaft coupler, the supplier has given me the website which identifies their partners outside the US:

https://www.servocity.com/international

When I decided to put together a pan set-up for my big Talon to carry a 2 axis brushless gimbal, I went looking for components that I could buy to build a stout 360+ degree pan mechanism that didn't need gears, belts or extra linkage parts and I found the components I needed in a company called Actobotics. This project then is an extension of that earlier work on my big Talon and some of the work I put into the Mini Talon.

After buying and building several Pan and Tilt set-ups I got tired of how cheaply the purchased ones were and how flimsy most were. The biggest problem has always been the pan axis is simply never robust enough. When I did find something that was strong enough (for me) it was always too heavy and too expensive or presented too much wind area.

With the Actobotics Pieces, their Futaba servo coupler and bearing plate, I was able to build a raised bearing that made the servo connection very strong. This structure keeps all the stresses off the servo shaft and its bearings and elliminates unwanted motion or wobble.

Included here are the STL files and a few pictures of what it looks like. I have set it up to be configurable with three different mounts for flat decks, three different camera plates to accomodate different cameras and a version that puts two cameras in an over-under configuration that could be used in a head tracking set-up. Please see the "PnT Configurations" picture for more ideas.

The 360 Servo
The base Pan servo is the current version of the GWS S125-1T Sail Winch servo. It has good centering characteristics, will actually travel 385 degrees, it's quite smooth and makes monster torque (~7kg). It is important to note that there are two versions of this servo, one with 23 tooth spline which was discontinued 2 years ago and the one for this project which has a 25 tooth spline identical to Futaba.

Parts and Specifications:
Bottom Unit Printed Parts
GWS Servo Plate
GWS Servo Deck Plate
Bearing Plate
Bearing Deck Plate

Top Unit Printed Parts
Tall Turret
Short Turret
Std Mobius Mount
Std Dual Camera Mount
Std Misc Camera Mount
Over-Under Camera Mount

Servos
Pan - GWS S125-1T (25 tooth)
Tilt - 9g servo

Hardware
1x Actobotics #525142 Servo Extension - 25 tooth
1x 0.375"ID x 0.625"OD x 0.156"L Ball Bearing
*1x 3" x 0.047" Steel Wire

Fasteners
2x M3 x 20mm Nylon PHS
4x M3 x 8mm SHCS
6x M3 Flat Washer
4x M2.5 x 8mm SHCS
4x M2.5 Flat Washer
4x M2 x 6mm SHCS
4x M2 Flat Washer
4x M3 x 15mm Aluminum Stand-offs

Weights and Measures
-Total weight with all hardware and a true 9g tilt servo - 93 grams
-Pan rotaion - 385 degrees
-Tilt range, single camera - 0-70 degrees (down)
-Tilt range, over-under camera - -19 (up) to 45 degrees (down)

For more detailed information and images please go to my Wiki project page at this link:

http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=Heavy_Duty_Pan_and_Tilt

See also-
Simple Compact Pan and Tilt: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1658134
Simple Offset Pan and tilt: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1658131
Lightweight Pan and Tilt: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2122735

This is my design of a Linear Bearing.
My printed ones have no noticeable backlash and they slide very easy.
So far there are no long-term tests, but I will use them in my printer so we will see.
The default outline is the same as an LM8UU, but it is changeable in OpenSCAD.

Print the thing, put through the appropriate drill and check if all teeth are separated. Notes:
  • it is recommended to print them in PLA, because it is harder
  • all walls should be only one string wide so the thing can adapt to the rod
  • all teeth should be separated and one should be able to look through them
    • Additional info:
  • with less teeth the thing slides harder (I did test down to four teeth)
  • with twisted toothâ€™s in rod direction applies an twisting force when they slide along.
    • OpenSCAD requires this lib https://github.com/kr2/MCAD to work with this I use https://github.com/kr2/OpenSCAD-build-script

I've printed some up, using Slic3r (my usual Cura made the tooth walls too thick), and filed them out until they slide effortlessly on my X axis rails.  I'm using a silicone lubricant with PTFE (similar to super lube) on the rails.  They tolerate fast motion beautifully (no signs of vibration or indication that they're binding), but with slow motion I run into a weird snag or lagging effect on my extruder head.  It can most often be seen when printing circles, where the left and rightmost edges are sort of "squashed" or squared off.  This seems to happen at the point where the X axis is moving slowest while drawing the circle.

comments.text: To be honest, I'd use PLA. Technically, ABS has more tensile strength and in the engineering world is considered the stronger material. However, this is not what you want in this case, You want a material that is harder/more rigid (PLA). These will work on even the worse quality rods. Whatever you use to hold this bearing, make sure it's adjustable. You can use this adjustment to collapse the printed bearing to accommodate slightly different diameter in rods. Print it in ABS or PLA, you'll be fine. Bottom line- the ABS might have more flex in it but will last longer: (14+ months plus).

description.text: I designed this small support to make a Pitot for my APM, because the original broke in a crash, i used two plastic tubes one with the front end opened and the second with it closed and two holes in the side to measure the static pressure.
Electrical Socket (IL)

I was looking for a desk fan and it seemed like everything I found was in excess of $15, had middling reviews, didn't last long, and was based on a brushed motor. My personal experience is I'm lucky if such a fan lasts a couple of years and they are certainly not very repairable. I figured I could do better.

I bought the following supplies on eBay:

  • 140mm brushless computer fan ($3.60)
  • USB DC 5V to 12V step-up module with 2.1x5.5mm plug ($1.65)
  • Male/female 2.1x5.5 jack/plug connector ($0.75)

At my local hardware store I bought a 6-pack of #6-32 x 1.5" coarse threaded Philips head screws and nuts (just a bit over $1). Of course, I only needed 4 of the 6.

Total cost: less than $8 in materials.

I then got down to designing the frame and stand that would hold the fan and allow it to tilt some. I designed it to be simple, easy to assemble/disassemble and, most importantly, easy to print.

It is possible to print everything without supports. However, the corner brackets print a touch better if you allow your slicer to add supports.

I will not give assembly instructions here - I'm guessing it should be pretty evident how it all goes together. No glue needed! The corner brackets comfortably hold the side panels in place with minimal wiggle. Tolerances are loose to allow for a wide variety of printers to print, even without calibration.

Please note I included two sizes of nuts - one scaled to 106% of the thread size, one to 107%. Depending on your tolerances you may need to choose one, the other, or perhaps even scale it a bit yourself.

The end product does move some air but perhaps not as much as some commercial units. However, I love the idea that I can plug this into any USB socket (even a portable power supply!) and I can replace the fan for very little money should it ever burn out.

DISCLAIMER

No, there isn't a fan guard. I work with mature adults who know better than to stick their fingers in a fan. While I doubt you will chop off any appendages that do manage to make their way into the blades, I would imagine it would hurt a decent amount and perhaps cause some damage to said appendages and the owner's ego.

IF YOU HAVE CHILDREN PLEASE KEEP THIS OUT OF THEIR REACH OR AT THE VERY LEAST PRINT A FAN GUARD. Thingiverse has many to choose from. I've used this one in the past:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:128718

I am NOT RESPONSIBLE for injuries should you chose to make this fan and someone sticks something in it they shouldn't. Please exercise common sense.

Should you choose to make this:
Happy printing! Let me know if you have questions in the comments and I'll do my best to answer promptly.

title: Mod Podge Image Transfer to 3D Printed Surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The other day picked up some small bottles of Matte and Gloss Mod Podge (https://plaidonline.com/mod-podge/brand/home.htm). While searching on the internet for ideas on what to use it for, I came across multiple You-Tube videos using Mod Podge type items to transfer images to wood surfaces. Hmmmm - how about onto 3D printed surfaces...

Not knowing if there was a difference between Gloss and Matte Mod Podge in performance, I decided to test both. First I created a test bed for using both types of Mod Podge I purchased as well as identifying color and black & white. In the videos, they used laser printed images. So I picked 4 images, 2 color and 2 black & white, sized them to be 1.5" x 1.5", laid them out according to the test bed, and printed - made sure to mirror or flip the image before printing in the print set up. (see attached image)

Following the same instructions on the videos, I smeared Mod Podge onto the test bed but aligned everything according to the column identifying the type of Mod Podge being used. Then I took the laser printed image and placed it image face down onto the Mod Podge and pressed it down, squeegeeing out any bubbles. The surface has to be smooth and relatively flat - cylindrical counts as flat but spherical does not. The test bed with the images were left to sit for over 24 hrs.

The next day, using water, I gently rubbed at the wet paper. Carefully and lightly I kept rubbing until all the paper was gone. Then I let the test bed sit to dry. About 1 hour later, there as a milky film still on the transferred images. So I repeated the steps of carefully and lightly rubbing at the surface with wet fingers until the surface felt paper free. Again, waited until it dried. Repeated this 2 more times before I was sure that all paper had been rubbed away and only the image was left behind.

In the videos they say to clear coat the images with either more mod podge, clear coat, varnish, etc. I opted not do anything with this experiment and will see how durable it is long term.

As for Glossy vs. Matte? I could not really tell a difference. Some of my friends said they thought the glossy had better light/dark contrast.

Soon I will repeat this experiment but instead of using laser printed images, I will use ink jet printed images.

The implementation is limited by ones imagination. I am thinking intricate details that can be printed and added in small areas on print surfaces.

If you do wind up using this technique, please share what you have made.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

.2

20%

Went with default settings. Test bed is very thin (<1mm) as it doesn't need to be thicker for the purpose of this experiment.

The different fonts are just a result of trying different fonts available in the PTC Creo Elements program I was using to see how they look printed out.

Image Transfer using Mod Podge

Same steps as described in multiple You-Tube videos for Image transfer onto wood using Mod Podge or gel or gloss, etc.

There is a Mod Podge for image transfer but it is more expensive.

Have seen Mod Podge at Walmart, Target, Michaels, Hobby Lobby, ...

Let sit for 24 hrs before washing/rubbing off the paper.

title: Clean Room Inlet Fan/Filter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is Thing-a-Week #5, previous things can be found here. http://www.iheartrobotics.com/search/label/thing-a-week Currently this is untested and experimental due to the holiday weekend and since it is still printing. These parts are used to build a positive pressure glove box style clean room.
The goal is to produce somewhere around a Class 10,000 cleanroom environment in a small space that is useful for taking things like hard drives, cameras and lasers apart. The current design uses a shopvac air filter part #VF3500, but part #VF6000 is probably preferred.
http://www.ridgid.com/Tools/Vac-Filters/EN/index.htm Based on initial estimates the RadioShack Cooling Fan part #273-0241 should provide reasonable performance when matched with the air filter, however testing has not yet been completed. Connecting rods are cut from 6061-T6 Round Aluminum tubing, and tapped M4.
OD 0.25" Wall Thickness 0.065"
http://www.onlinemetals.com/merchant.cfm?pid=6844&step=4&showunits=inches&id=71&top_cat=60 The open endcap connects to the fan using M3 countersunk screws and nuts. The design may require caulk or gaskets to function properly.

Print and assemble according to the exploded view diagram.
Cut and tap connecting rods to length. Use a file to trim the length of the rods to ensure a tight fit. NEW INSTRUCTIONS HERE
http://www.iheartrobotics.com/2010/02/this-new-lab-diy-cleanroom.html

I would think if they make a compatible vacuum that is certified the certified filters are going to be available for sure.

author: LucidOne

description.text:
George Orwell's 1984 is here in your living room with Xbox Kinect. (Sure, GM has had Onstar for a while, but that is audio only.)
We call the Kinect the "Eye of Sauron" so print and pop Sauron's Shades on for that romantic interlude or whenever you want to put the blinders on Sauron without the hassle of turning it completely off. Just remember audio is still on.

Designed for Print 'O Matic 2 shells .3mm layer height 20% fill. Sauron's front face text is inset .9mm. It's right at 100mm so should fit on a HBP just fine and is just long enough to cover the lenses on the Kinect. You may consider stretching it a tad if you're well set up and know your max dimensions I've been contemplating a hole aligned with the Power LED but haven't yet. This because how are you going to know Sauron's Shades aren't just mis-aligned and power really is on? Probably I'll put it in to the design file. You can drill this hole as in the picture. 1.5" from the left side and 11/16" up from the bottom. It's close to the side of the U so start with a 1/16th bit and work up - otherwise the bit will walk into the channel and re-center there. I worked up to a 1/4" bit and that seems fine. This was designed in Autodesk 123D. I can't tell you which version - as I can find no way from the program to find that out. (2/27/2012) It's kind of a love-hate relationship. What it does it does very well - and that makes you fight what you then assume it will do well - but doesn't. I can say that you should peruse their help forum topics and for what you don't find ask with a new posting. They are exceedingly responsive and helpful. Fixed stl text reversal and changed placement on build platform for flat not tall print. Acquired a MK7 during the few hours it was available and will reprint and post that picture soon. I've printed this top down and it's prone to cracking from the hot top surface to the more rapidly cooling front and back edges. If this doesn't go too horribly you can check the cracks with a 1/16th hole at the tip of the crack (distributes forces) and some glue. I've even tried adding HBP
temp control gcodes to walk the temp down with mixed results. That might work if done after the very first layer. Right now I'm trying printing on end. Almost got one with the MK6 but it came loose on the bottom. So MK-7 and a raft? Well, between MK7 and dating ReplicatorG and firmware I can't get it to print this as anything but a half inchish rectangle. Something is amiss but I haven't isolated that yet. Likely large file bug with new RG / FW?

comments.text: The the file is named after the child of Sauron and Saruman? The file name is a little off.
comments.author: GlitchTech

comments.text: I may well be not understanding something, but the word "Sauron" is reversed on the image (above) of the STL file image.  When I open your 123D file in my copy of 123D, it also displays the word that way.  And two different .stl file viewers confirm that for your .stl file.  Yet the gray image above shows it reading correctly.  I'm confused!

description.text:
My dad is aging further into his forties, but insists that he is just "almost fifty" so I made him a keychain based on the "PLATEZ" design to give him a tangible representation of his crisis.

This is a remix of the "PLATEZ" but their cc license does not allow derivatives. I made this from scratch in Fusion 360. I just used the measurements from the model they posted. I also made an OpenSCAD file but I found someone else had already made one.

title: Tiny Whoop Mullet - Mohawk Mod + Vacuum Box

description.text:
Cut lines are included in the model. I printed the box in PETG vs PLA to resist the heat generated by the heat gun, and it seems to work fine. The vacuum hose hole is 35mm. Trim or fill it to fit your vacuum hose. Use a 4" bamboo hoop to hold the polystyrene sheet. Polystyrene sheet used here is 0.02" thick.

Tip: see the end of my video (link below) so see how I installed the canopy on the frame. I used the flight controller's screws to bolt the canopy down to the frame. It works much better than using the side tabs.

Here is my tutorial: https://youtu.be/gKx1zs5B3WI

author: muppis

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in one print without oozing with the new Multex2Move designed by multec.

description.text:
This gyroscope was printed in one print by our new Multex2Move Extruder - a patented oozing free dual- and quad-extruder.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=orvDOLtIyag
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVwlfbbdfLM6UOeD_VjbU4g
Thanks to an elaborate mechanism, the unused nozzles of the new four-color extruder Multex4Move are retracted behind a cover and only the active nozzle is brought into the operating range. Hereby it prevents molten plastic from dripping out of the unused nozzles and onto the printed object and disfiguring the printing result. Before switching to another nozzle, it is first cleaned before being put into the operating range to prevent possible impurities.

Read more:
https://www.multec.de/Multex4Move-quad-extruder-world-first

The Multex2Move soon will be available on kickstarter, if you wan´t to be informed about the progress or the kickstarter campagne, please subscribe to our newsletter:
https://www.multec.de/newsletter.php

Multec delivers innovation for even more variety

With the Multex4Move, Multec delivers a new innovation which makes 3D printing even more diverse and professional. Besides using different colors, the Multex4Move offers the possibility to use different materials for the printed object or support structures - with a yet unknown clean printing result. In this manner, printed objects might for example have specfic areas made out of flexible material, while others are made out of stiff material, which offers the possibilities for an incredible amount of printed objects.

In addition, the Multex4Move offers the User unknown possibilities, since even nozzles of different diameters can be used in one single extruder.

Also available as upgrade kit for printers of different brands

Small, compact versions of this innovative extruder will soon be available to upgrade existing 3D printers made by other manufacturers.
This way, many printers which did not deliver satisfying results can be optimized.

Printer:

Multirap M420

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 Layer height

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Printed in one print without oozing with the new Multex2Move designed by multec.

Needed new mounts for my quads after upgrading form a hero 4 to 5 session. Openings for the USB/SD door, front LED, both front and back mics, and the back button. Pretty snug fit, so added the 2 finger slots on either side to get the gopro out, making it pretty easy when mounted to a frame. Tight enough that it wont come out in a hard crash. Print in tpu and they are pretty much indestructible in a crash. Front edges provide plenty of lens protection.

Basic enclosure for protection - Updated 3/7/17
Red20RC BDX Racer Mount (goes over the 2 standoffs on the pod) - 17g @20% infill - One version old, can see a tiny but of the case in super view
Red20RC Kermit (2 screws into the front standoffs and a ziptie) - Pretty old at this point compared to the newest enclosure. Updating once I get my Kermit flying again.

author: CGS2001

title: BOXOI (3D Zoetrope DIY Kit) Laser-Cut Files

description.text:
Last year, me and my bro started a Kickstarter project called "BOXOI - 3D Zoetrope DIY Kit". The funding failed. This year, we try to reduce cost by using die-cutting parts instead of laser-cutting parts, and we simplify it by keeping only 1 play disk. (The 2 12-frammers are impossible for die-cutting anyway.)

Anyway, it would be a waste to just discard the 12-framers. We would like to share the laser cut files to makers who are interested, able to handle the EE parts themselves, and have access to a laser-cutter to make their own BOXOI. The EE parts including the motor should be easy to find online. The gear ratio of the motor that I use is 1:48.

You'll need a reflective optical sensor facing up the platform for timing, and 2 black stripes on the back of the play disk (1 stripe for the 6-frammer). You can either paint it or simply use a black PVC tape for this job. Program your strobe light to flash six times per signal, 1ms per time.

You can see how it works in our old video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MOYvPVzwH4c

  • This is a later version of BOXOI laser cut file, the power switch was removed. It was programmed to start by the push button and turns off automatically after say 45 secs, For those who would like to simplify it with a power switch, a battery box that comes with a power switch can be a good alternative.

** For BOXOI2 backers, you need only Boxoi_B.svg for the 12 framers. The platform will be compatible.

title: Easy Filament Storage free Standing or in Shelf

description.text:
Hello there. This is a easy to Print Filament Storage System which you can either put Free Standing on your Desk, or Mount it to any Shelf, in this Case the Shelf Mount is directly compatible to IKEA's BILLY Shelf and the Filament Storage will be mountable to that.

You'll need some Screws and Aluminum Rods which you can get in any department store.
Screws:
M5 Hex/Allen with a Length of 12 or 14mm (for Ikea Billy) (4 per Shelf)
Hollow or Massive Aluminium Rods with 12mm Diameter, Length is up to you or the Width or
your Shelf. (In Case of the Billy cut the Rods to 76cm)

Print two Parts of either the "Holder for Billy" or "Holder Free Standing"
For the Shelf Holder, screw the M5 Screws into the smaller Holes.
Put the Aluminium Rods into the bigger Holes and put it into the Shelf.
For the Free Standing Version i Recommend to add Rubber Stoppers underneath.

The Labels can be used to organize your Filaments by Types.
The Label can easily be mounted to the Rails by pulling the two Rods slightly
together and attaching the Label there. The Label can be moved easily to adjust
to changing Filament Stock.

In the Downloads i provided the Source Files for you to edit if necessary (123dx)

Please let me know if you have any questions!

Best regards
Philipp

description.text:
Replacement parcel shelf hangers for a Mazda 6 liftback (may work on hatch too I don't have one to test).

Originally the string is held in the top hanger with a clip, that's too small to reliably replicate on FDM so this just has a hole to put the string through.

For the string I suggest something strong like perhaps the same kind of string used on roll up window blinds, just don't tell the wife why the blinds are missing their strings.

Optional title:

If you open the scad file you should notice the clip has various colours. This makes it easy to tweak if need be but also marks the cyan pieces which will need to be trimmed about half way with a sharp knife after printing. They're there on the original clips but their proximity to the button section means they also act as built in support while printing and will be slightly fused to the lower orange section.

description.text:
Based off of Spacecow1's Thermos Opener http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1301687

Changes I made:

Beveling, beveling everywhere! Uses less plastic and is more comfortable to hold.

  • Beveled handle and sides removes any sharp edges, is more comfortable
  • Beveled socket helps guide the wrench onto the cap
  • Moved the "THERMOS" labeling from the handle to the middle of the socket
  • Added a hole in the handle to allow it be hung on a peg or by string, maybe tie it to your Thermos
  • Slightly tweaked the connecting angle from the socket to the handle

After the Thermos cools down a little bit there is often a quite strong vacuum which keeps that top on quite tight. Use the Thermos Opener v2 to help break that seal.

print_settings.Notes:: Using Cura 15: with rafting and support it will take 1Hour 32Mins and about 3.5M of filament weighing about 10g.

description.text:
This is an extruder cable support for the 3D Printer Anet A6. I designed it when I realized that my cable trunking always get caught in the way of the end stop limit switch of the X axis. So to bypass this, I made a support piece that will elevate the cable trunking whilst not obstructing the feeding of the filament as well as the threaded rods. It works well now!

PLEASE REMEMBER TO PRINT IN THE ORIENTATION FOLLOWING THE PHOTOS.

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm, 0.2mm/layer height

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

Material is PLA, 175mm
Working Temperatures: Extruder 210°C, Heated Bed: 55°C

Using Cura 15: with rafting and support it will take 1Hour 32Mins and about 3.5M of filament weighing about 10g.

Mounting Instructions to the Printer
  1. Once finished printing, it should look like this with the supports added and rafting.
  2. Remove the rafts and the support.
  3. Apply a layer of sponged double sided tape on the 'legs' of the support. (I used VHB tape from 3M.) Clean up the surface with IPA for good adhesion.
  4. Stick the support in this direction as shown. The legs should be on the fan's cage as well as the front of the Extruder motor.
  5. Place the Cable trunking (near the Y-Fork) on top of the support piece. Then secure it with a cable tie that loops over the trunking and support.
  6. And you are done! You are ready to go about printing!

comments.text:
Little hint: The main bunch of cables to the printers extruder are supposed to hang down from the top of the printer's frame.
That way, the cable-roll nearly "stands" on the extruder pushing the cables up in a bow even when reaching the top z-position.
Try that setup and if you then tie the heater-, extruder-motor- and fan-cables tight together near the extruder-motor, your problem with cables will be solved without the need of a stand.
comments.author: McSchweg

comments.text: What if you needed to take your fan off of the extruder to clear jams, adjust spring tension, etc.? Wont the adhesive tape prevent you from separating the two?
comments.author: jantzenday

comments.text: You can change the adhesive tape to Velcro tape in the event if you want to regularly clear jams or adjust spring tensions. In my opinion, the tape is a consumable that I wouldn't mind changing.
comments.author: jantzenday

title: Greg's X-Ends without Upper Nut Trap

description.text:
This is a simple modification to GregFrost's excellent Prusa X-ends that removes the column for the upper nut trap.  I don't use top nuts, so printing the nut traps would have been a waste of plastic and time.
This was a direct modification to the STL file, so there is no openscad or solidworks "source" file.
The STL has already been run through netfabb, so it shouldn't produce any errors.

Print, install, enjoy.
As I found out, these even work with half of the top bearing holder missing (thanks, skipped steps!).  As long as you can get about 50% of the top bearing in the plastic and a zip tie on it, you're good to go.

description.text:
Hands On Search Web site
http://sawareru.jp/en/

I've upgraded the existing model to a double headed screw with the nut captured inside.
This could be a good way to challenge people to try to get the nut out (but be careful they don't break it)
The catch is how to put the nut inside -
With the slic3r (or any other modeling software) position two instances of the screw with some distance between them.

Once there is enough height to the screw, pause the printing while the extruder is on one of the screws, and put the nut on the other (be careful not to move it from the surface). Resume the printing and then put the remaining nut on the other screw.

Notice that the nuts have to be printed before the screws and I recommend scaling them a bit bigger (so putting them on the screw would be easier).

comments.text:

author: vmk78

title: Ultimate Magic Wand with Tricks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the Ultimate Magic Wand !!

By reading further you must agree to keep the magic secret (but it can be told to your apprentice...)

Do you agree?

Well do you?

Are you sure?

Ok I take it that you have thought long and hard about it, and have agreed!

Wahoo !!

Welcome to the other side of Magic!

**Updated : ***
Added a Joiner so you can double the size of the wand! ...now its adult size!!
Added a Magic Box for the Growing Wand Trick
Added a New Star Wand End (for the extra little Magicians)
Added a Video demonstration of the How-To

Building your 'Wand'!

This is the ultimate magic wand and tho it may look like 3 wands to the untrained eye all magicians know it is really the same wand. ;)

Things to Note:
Parts have been made to fit firmly in most cases, a slight sanding, drill or glue may be required. (dependant on your printer)

Construction wand 1

Printed Parts:
1x Wand Body
2x Standard End
1x Tight Fit Tip
1x Soft Fit Tip
1x Plug

Parts:
Millinery Elastic (Hat Elastic)
1 X Tubular magnets 4mm x 4mm
Glue (for magnets)

Hint:
Feed elastic through once then back up, stretch thread and tie off (must be a firm fit)
Elastic seems to bounce back nicer but frays a bit after some use (Jelly Elastic may not to bounce back as nicely but won’t fay)

Construction wand 2

Printed Parts:
1x Wand Body
1x Standard End
1x Hollow End
1x Tight Fit Tip
1x Soft Fit Tip
2x Magnet Holder
1x Plug

Parts:
Millinery Elastic (Hat Elastic)
3 X Tubular Magnets 4mm x 4mm
Glue (for Magnets)
Tinsel 5mm x 5mm or something Shiny

Hint:
Feed elastic through once then back up and tie off (must be a loose fit)
Make sure poles of magnets are the correct way around before gluing…. yeah oops

Construction wand 3

Printed Parts:
1x Mini Body
2x Mini Tip

Parts:
glue

Stick:

Printed Parts:
Stick

Hint : This isn't required as you can use a pencil instead

Magic Box

Printed Parts:
1x Lid
1x Box
1x Base
Little bit of fillament

Hint:
The Holes may need to be drilled out with a 2mm bit drill bit, break off a but of filament and use it as the "wire" for the Hinge then use a lighter to melt the end and flatten

Kids wand

Printed Parts:
1x Wand Body
1x Standard End
1x Tight Fit Tip
1x Plug
1x Star Front
1x Star Back

Parts:
Millinery Elastic (Hat Elastic)
1 X Tubular Magnets 4mm x 4mm
Glue (for Magnets)
1 x Item to appear
1 x a bit of wire of the Hinge
1x fishing wire

Hint:
I have added a magnet to the standard end as it is easy, Make sure the elastic on the star is Taut as it needs to bounce back easily
CCSS
Magic of illusion is an art that has been around for...ever or so many believe.
Lesson Plan : Illusion and what the eye sees isn't always what is happening

Glue
Elastic
Magnets
Clips

• #Magic
  • #Communication
  • #SlightOfHand
  • #Deception
  • #acting

The Magic!

Bellow are just a few tricks than can be achieved with this 'Wand' but of course this is just the beginning

Trick 1 Growing wand

Required:
watch or band
long sleeves
Magic Box
Wand 1
Mini wand

Setup:
Tuck Wand under watch band or Hair Tie

Trick:
Small Wand is placed in box and a big wand is pulled out of small purse

How to:
Show off small wand which is too small for Big Magic
Pick up Magic Box and show it's empty
Place small wand in box
Push big wand into back of Magic Box
Pull big wand through hole and out of purse
Magic!

Accept the adoration of your audience and any goats that are offered.

Trick 2 Floating wand

Required:
Wand 1 or 2

Setup:
None

Trick:
Wand Sticks to hand miraculously

How to:
Hold wand in right hand
Grip the right wrist left hand (except pointer finger that will hold the wand)
Open right hand
Magic!

Accept the Esteem and Love of your audience with slight nod of knowing how good you really are

Trick 3 Floating wand next level

Required:
Wand 1 or 2
watch or band
long sleeves
Stick

Setup:
Tuck printed stick (or a pencil) under watch band

Trick:
Wand Sticks to hand miraculously (and you are not even holding your wrist)

How to:
Hold wand in right hand
With Left hand pull out stick to hold the wand (should still also be under band)
Open right hand
Magic!

Accept the Reverend silence of a shocked audience with slight rise of the eyebrow of a Master Magician

Trick 4 Rubber wand

Required:
Wand 1

Setup:
None

Trick:
The wand looks like it is made of rubber

How to:
Hold wand between thumb index finger ¾ down the wand loosely
Move hand up and down slowly
Magic!

Accept the inundation of applause knowing your audience’s childlike wonder has not peaked until this day

Trick 5 Sticky Wand

Required:
Wand 1
Paper Clip
Audience Member

Setup: Add a pile of Paper clips to the table

Trick: Wand placed on paper clips and they magically stick, wand gives audience member and nothing happens

How to:
Ask for an audience member
Place wand on paper clip (Magnetic end of Wand 1)
Take off paper clip
Hand directly to audience member (So Non Magnetic end is pointing out)
Get Audience Member to pick up paper clips…Nothing
Magic!

Watch your dumbfound audience try to grapple with your amazing mind numbing magic ability

Trick 6 Rising Wand

Required:
Wand 1

Setup:
None

Trick:
The wand rises by itself, no matter how much you tell it off after pushing it down it rises

How to:
Set Right hand into the shape of a karate chop
Take the elastic end of wand 1 and place it between your index and middle finger facing back of hand
Place wand in palm of hand holding wand with thumb
Press down on top of wand with left hand and hold in place with right thumb
Loosen right thumb and the wand should rise
Repeat (and tell it off for moving)
Let go of elastic end and re-fit to wand
Magic!

Accept the crowds roaring laughter knowing that this day your audience knows what true joy really is!

Trick 7 Ghost Wand

Required:
Wand 1
Black thread one end tied to a knot the other end tied button on shirt
Glass Bottle with small neck

Setup:
Wear Shirt that has a button with a thread dangling down (knot at the end)

Trick: Wand moves at its own free will and no hands

How to:
Slip knot in to elastic end of wand (open wand end and close it on knot)
Place Wand in Bottle
Move your body back and forth slowly and the wand should rise and fall without touching it
Magic!

Calm the hysteria created by the Ghost Wand, pick any weak willed people that have fainted (maybe providing a cool glass of water) and promise that the ghost will not come back and that the shock they received will ease in time… and accept the shocked applause

Trick 8 Wand through a Note

Required:
Wand 2
$5 Note or handkerchief

Setup:
None

Trick:
Wand is pushed through a note and ripped off with no harm to the note

How to:
Hold the long end of the wand in one hand hiding the missing end
Hold the Short end in the other hand hidden
Pick up note and say you're going to push your wand through it
Push Wand from heel of hand on one side of note
Line up other end of wand and they should join magnetically Wand-Paper-Wand
Show it off
Then rip the wand sideways (and the note should be gone with no rip and the wand still connected)
Magic!

Watch the audience’s faces turn from the horror of defacing a note to absolute relief and nirvana, when the note has no damage then stand back for the standing ovation as roses are thrown on stage from your many many worshipers and admires

Trick 9 Final Finnish Sparkles

Required:
Wand 2
Cut 5mm squared tinsel, or sparkles/glitter (but will get everywhere!)

Setup:
Open Wand 2 container end
Fill end with tinsel (don’t pack it hard!)
Close end

Trick:
Waving the wand in the air produces a shower of golden sparkles

How to:
Open end
Swing wand gently in the air in circles (Sparkles should come out automatically)
Close End
Magic!

Take a bow and accept the audiences undying love and gratitude, and take their tears of joy as a clinching proof that you are a master Magician, accept any offers of marriage or money (where applicable)

.
The lights go down but they want more !! But as you are a performer of much respect and Honor how could you let the crowd down!! But wait maybe the best idea is to send out the little apprentice, and you be the helper!

Encore
Trick 10 Kids Floating Wand

Required:
Star Wand

Setup:
None

Trick:
The Wand is Floating!!!

How to:
Take out Fishing line from the star wand
Magic!

Watch the audience’s faces see your true wonder that 'your' apprentice is as amazing!! and you are a true master.

Trick 11 Kids Appear

Required:
Star Wand

Setup:
Small it Cloth

Trick:
Small Cloth appears from no where!

How to:
Show Wand from all angles
Take out Cloth from the star wand

Magic!

Hear the audience’s Cheers of amazement! as this mini apprentice has defied reality and the crowd realise how gracious you are, to share the stage with your awesome apprentice... for you are a true teacher and Master Magician.

.

After the lights have gone down and the cheering has died away and you sit in your mansion that was paid for by your amazing Magical Talent maybe just maybe you could throw a copper my way, remembering this is where it all started …. I won’t complain. :)

author: cyde

description.text:
This is a small about 4 inch model of the world famous Delicate Arch located in Arches National Park by Moab Utah. The arch was captured accurately in 3D using a FARO Focus 3D laser scanner as well as some areas captured using the free Autodesk 123D Catch which turns multiple photos from a digital camera to 3D models. I am posting the small reduced sized STL file so everyone can 3D print their own Delicate Arch. The lines produced from a MakerBot add even more realism to this sandstone arch and you can even wash it lightly with acetone to smooth it up . The fine detailed arch is actually gigabytes in size. You can see more on the creation of this model at
http://autodesk.blogs.com/between_the_lines/2012/02/delicate-arch-in-your-hand-as-a-3d-print.html
The STL file has been reduced down to a size and complexity that can be printed on a MakerBot ToM.

description.text:
Hi!

Recently i bought an Arcade Controller Kit (http://www.ebay.es/itm/201344779838) and always wanted a big case so i designed this.

Not need much explanation. Just print an assemble.

Great for classics arcades on MAME emulator.

Only need some screws for fixing the joystick.

The modules are joined using some 'pins' and some glue. Lateral parts fits without glue. and covers for buttons and joystick just fits without glue or screws.

You have room for 6 buttons (30 mms) on top, one 30 mm button on every side (great for pinballs) and two 24 mms buttons in central module (Used for Coin and Start).

The central piece have room for the 'electronics' and i don't use any support, just put inside and conect all the wires.

Tip: Glue some EVA foam at bottom to get a good grip on table.
Tip:Use some 'cyanocrilate' based glue for PLA. Works really well.

Also has customized joystick!! I've included 2 customized joysticks for replacing the red ball: The european stick and a pac-man. Just screw on the metal bar.

Hope you enjoy it.
Have Fun!!

Printer:

BQ Prusa i3 Hephestos

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Tested with PLA and NO supoprts. A bit of overhanging on inner parts but the exterior it's OK

Use a 0.3 resolution for a fast printing and 15 or 20% infill in order to have a strong structure.

title: Anet A6 Duct + V2 - Anet A6 ventillation

description.text:
aration_a6.stl (accent issue when upload :-) )
Is an adaptation from one planned for A8. Very large to the point of not being able to see the beginnings of printing to make sure everything goes well. Another thing, I use clamps to hold a boroscilate glass and this piece took up so much space that the clamps were ejected when impressions on the edges
a6_fan_duct_v2_with_support.stl (better name no? :-) )
All the problems noted above are corrected with a somewhat revised ventilation so that the direction of the holes for the air flow arrives just below the nozzle. Definitely not perfect yet but I am satisfied with the result.
I add support because Slic3r is unable to make support only with buildplate. If you use Cura select "Touching buildplate"

a6_fan_duct_v3_with_support and gap.stl
It's the same than V2 with gap

The cable chaos on Ramps bother me for a long time. Many housing make it not really better. The chaos is only hiding. Now, it the Ramps was never built for a closed installation.
I searched a better solution. I think I have found them. All connections are led out after a side. The control can be connected quickly easily in other projects.
The prototype includes a Raspberry Pi 3 as the host. Another lid can also take up a Raspberry Pi B+.
The use of the second extrusion is also prepared. The perforated parts must be removed.
Only two plug connectors and a fanextender are necessary.
I use PSS254 2G und PSS254 4W. Why? I have of it more than enough and the plugs are in the 2.45 mm of grid. They are also compatible with Dupontconnector, they are widespread.
The final version becomes a little broader and gets a PCB with solder pads.

When it looked like hurricane Matthew was going to hit South Florida, I put up my hurricane shutters, which required the screwing in of many wingnuts. This was kind of a pain doing by hand, so when it came time to take them down, I went to several hardware stores looking for an attachment that would let me remove the wingnuts using my cordless drill. Well, there weren't any to be found, so I created one and it works great. Used ASA plastic, which is designed for outdoor use. No particular reason for using that. It's just what I happened to have loaded at the time. Also printed using 100% infill.

https://youtu.be/KA2fBcaWAg8
